INDIANAPOLIS ZOO

2023 ANNUAL REPORT

MISSION

IN bloom

P:02

Photo: Indianapolis Zoo

P:03

Mission:

The Indianapolis Zoo

protects nature and inspires

people to care for our world.

Vision:

We believe in a world where

nature and people thrive.

Core Values:

We are one team.

We care.

We welcome everyone.

We have integrity.

We strive for excellence.

Vision

2023 Annual Report 2

P:08

A MESSAGE FROM THE

President & CEO

When I walk through the front

entry of the Zoo, I am awed by

the transformation. In 2023, we

unveiled a stunning, $5 million entry

experience, rolling out the âgreenâ

carpet and inviting guests to leave

the outside world behind.

Wandering through White River

Gardens, meeting Wild Encounter

animal ambassadors and exploring the

Global Center for Species Survival,

guests are now immersed in the

natural world from the first moment of

their visit. It is an engaging experience

that rejuvenates and refreshes. I am

convinced that it also propels our

mission forward by reminding all

visitors that we protect nature and

inspire people to care for our world.

Through our exhibits, programming

and constellation of conservation

efforts, we embody what it means

to be a modern zoo. Our team has

successfully built an organization

that embraces our local community

while having authentic influence

nationally and internationally.

Focused on the vision of a world

where nature and people thrive, we

move forward with creativity, drive

and relentless optimism.

I am proud and privileged to lead

this remarkable organization. I am

also tremendously grateful for the

enthusiastic support we receive from

our community.

Sincerely,

Dr. Robert W. Shumaker

president & ceo

3 IndianapolisZoo.com

Chimpanzee

2023 Annual Report 4

P:10

The Indianapolis Zoo welcomes more

than one million visitors each year. In

2023, we opened our new front entry

and Visitor Services Center, elevating

our entrance to a truly distinctive

and memorable experience. This

investment reshapes the Zoo, using

nature as our guide. Starting at the

Indianapolis Colts Welcome Plaza,

guests first step into the lush White

River Gardens using the Allen Whitehill

Clowes Nature Path to meander

through landscaped archways, pausing

at fountains and whimsical sculptures

and engaging with animal ambassadors

such as a parrot, sloth or aardvark.

The Nina Mason Pulliam Grand

Concourse leads guests through the

Global Center for Species Survival,

which includes a dynamic display

that highlights the diversity of

life on Earth. The impact of the

Zooâs field conservation work is

vividly illustrated. Stunning wildlife

images and video from National

Geographic Photo Ark photographer

and Indianapolis Prize honoree Joel

Sartore are inspirational. Guests will

feel grounded in our vision of a world

where nature and people thrive.

GROWING

Our Garden

PENGUIN PROTECTOR

Honored

Pablo Borboroglu, PhD, wins 2023 Indianapolis Prize

The international conservation

community celebrated the ninth

winner of the Indianapolis Prize,

Argentinian penguin ecologist Dr.

Pablo Borboroglu. United States

Ambassador to Argentina, Marc

Stanley, presented Dr. Borboroglu with

the Indianapolis Prize award at the

September 2023 gala in downtown

Indianapolis. Known as the worldâs

leading award for animal conservation,

the Prize celebrates an animal

conservation scientist who has

achieved major victories in their work

to save a species or group of species.

The Prize grants $250,000 to the

winner, the largest individual monetary

award for animal conservation. Since

the first Prize gala in 2006, nearly $7

million has been granted.

Dr. Borboroglu is an expert on

penguin ecology and land and sea

conservation in countries around the

world, including his home country of

Argentina. Dr. Borboroglu has spent

more than three decades studying

penguins and leading conservation

efforts across four continents. He has

worked to improve penguin colony

management through the creation of

large, protected areas, including

32 million acres of ocean and coastal

habitat. He is the founder of the

Global Penguin Society, an

international conservation coalition

for the worldâs penguin species, and is

also the founder and co-chair of the

International Union for Conservation

of Natureâs Species Survival

Commission Penguin Specialist Group.

photo: S. Sere

AdÃ©lie penguin

Pygoscelis adeliae

photo: provided by Dr. Pablo Borboroglu

P:15

2023 Annual Report 10

P:16

PERUVIAN PRIMATOLOGIST

Celebrated

Fanny M. Cornejo named

inaugural Emerging Conservationist

In 2023, the Indianapolis Prize awarded

the first Emerging Conservationist

Award to Peruvian primatologist and

anthropologist Fanny M. Cornejo for

her work to encourage sustainable

economic development and protect

habitat for threatened species in Peru.

The Emerging Conservationist Award

recognizes and provides support to

conservationists under 40 years of

age who have the talent and drive to

make a significant impact on saving

species. She received $50,000, thanks

to a grant from the Kobe Foundation,

to support her conservation work.

The award catapulted Cornejo forward

in her career, landing her on the cover

of Forbes in Peru for her work to

protect the yellow-tailed woolly

monkey, an endangered species found

only in the Peruvian Andes.

Yellow-tailed woolly monkey

Oreonax flavicauda

Photo: Wilhelm Osterman

photo: Gerson Ferrer

P:17

photo: Gerson Ferrer

2023 Annual Report 12

P:18

NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC PHOTOGRAPHER

in the Spotlight

Joel Sartore named

2023 Jane Alexander Global Wildlife Ambassador

Wildlife photographer and National

Geographic Explorer Joel Sartore was

named the 2023 Jane Alexander

Global Wildlife Ambassador for his

use of stunning photography to

inspire people to save species from

extinction before itâs too late.

In 2006, Sartore and National

Geographic founded the Photo Ark

project to inspire people to protect

at-risk species through documentary

photography and video. To date,

Sartore has captured more than

47,000 images and videos for the

Photo Ark featuring 15,000 species.

First awarded in 2012, the Jane

Alexander Global Wildlife Ambassador

Award was created to recognize the

contributions of the remarkable

people who are sharing their passion

for wildlife with others. Conservation

does not stop with scientists in

the field. It relies on the help of

ambassadors to inspire and encourage

others to find their way to help.

Named in honor of award-winning

actress and dedicated conservationist

Jane Alexander, this award is given to

someone who supports the natural

world by leading others to action and

lending a credible, consistent and

effective public voice for the

sustainability of wildlife.

Photo: Matt Mays

Seal

Pinnipedia

2023 Annual Report 14

P:20

CONSERVATION

in Action

Ascension

Island Government

SCALY CRICKETS

Ascension Island is located in the

South Atlantic Ocean, about

halfway between South America

and Africa. It is home to several

species of crickets, which are

covered in iridescent scales. Scaly

crickets live in sandy areas and on

old lava flows. Non-native plants

and insects are putting scaly

crickets at risk of extinction. The

Indianapolis Zoo supports the

Ascension Island Government in

efforts to learn more about scaly

crickets. Scientists can share

what they learn about these

crickets to help protect them on

their oasis in the sea.

Each year, the Indianapolis Zoo provides grant support to wildlife conservation

projects across the world. In 2023, the Zoo supported 16 projects, helping to save

animals, plants and fungi in diverse habitats on multiple continents.

2023 Indianapolis Zoo Conservation Grant Awardees:

Western gorilla

Gorilla gorilla

photo: Wade Tregaskis

Atelopus Survival Initiative

HARLEQUIN TOADS

Harlequin toads are found in forests

and aquatic habitats in the neotropics

of Central and South America and get

their name from their many vibrant

colors. They have important cultural

significance in some countries and

Indigenous communities. Many species

of harlequin toads are endangered or

threatened with extinction from

different causes. The Indianapolis Zoo

supports the Atelopus Survival

Initiativeâs work to protect harlequin

toads and to study the threats against

them. The Initiative is bringing many

groups of people together to save

these iconic amphibians.

15 IndianapolisZoo.com

P:21

AZA SAFE Chimpanzee

CHIMPANZEES

Chimpanzees live in forests across

Central Africa. They rely on the

resources of forestsâespecially fruitsâ

to survive and thrive. Chimpanzees are

an endangered species because of loss

of forest habitat, hunting and disease.

The Indianapolis Zoo supports the

Association of Zoos & Aquariums

Chimpanzee Saving Animals From

Extinction (SAFE) program to help

save chimpanzees. They help people at

zoos and in conservation groups work

together to take action to protect

chimpanzees, focusing on reducing

poaching, habitat loss and disease in

chimpanzee populations.

Botanic Gardens

Conservation International

COLOMBIAN TREES

Colombia is home to thousands of

different kinds of trees. Hundreds of

tree species in Colombia are at risk of

extinction because of deforestation,

threatening local ecosystems. The

Indianapolis Zoo supports Botanic

Gardens Conservation International

in working to save trees. They are

using data from scientists to plan

actions in Colombia that will have

the biggest impact for trees. By

focusing on trees, Botanic Gardens

Conservation International will help

protect many species that live in

forests, including people.

Harlequin toad

Atelopus spumarius

photo: Andreas Kay

16

P:22

continued from previous page

Cheetah Conservation Fund

CHEETAHS

Cheetahs are top predators in the

grasslands of eastern and southern Africa.

Cheetah populations are shrinking because

of habitat loss and conflict with livestock

and people. Protecting wild cheetahs

requires cooperation with local farmers.

The Indianapolis Zoo supports the work of

the Cheetah Conservation Fund (CCF) to

help cheetahs in Namibia. They are

studying where cheetahs live and where

they have conflict with farms in Namibia.

CCF research can lead to the creation of

better habitats for cheetahs. Other

carnivoresâAfrican wild dogs and

leopardsâand farm animals also benefit

from this project. Research into cheetah

lifestyles makes it possible for people and

cheetahs to live in the same area.

Goualougo

Triangle Ape Project

AFRICAN GREAT APES

Great apes face many threats,

including loss of forest habitat,

hunting and disease. Since 2015, the

Indianapolis Zoo has supported the

Goualougo Triangle Ape Project in

working to protect chimpanzees and

gorillas in Central Africa. They conduct

research and build conservation

programs in Congo, working with local

community partners.

Southern African cheetah

Acinonyx jubatus

photo: Fred Cate

17

P:23

Hellbender Project

HELLBENDERS

Hellbenders are the largest salamander

in North America. They live in

freshwater streams and rivers in

Indiana and in other nearby states.

Hellbenders use rocky areas in streams

and rivers to lay their eggs. They are

at risk of extinction because of river

dams, water pollution and climate

change. Chemicals pass through their

skin into their bodies, making them

sensitive to environmental changes.

The Indianapolis Zoo supports plans

coordinated by Purdue University to

save hellbenders. Many people are

teaming up to improve habitat and to

raise and release hellbenders into

Indiana waterways. Conservationists

hope to increase the number of

hellbenders in Indiana for the future.

Indiana UniversityâPurdue

University Columbus

INDIANA MAYFLIES

Mayflies are insects and key members

of healthy freshwater ecosystems. At

least 24 mayfly species have not been

seen in Indiana for 40 years or more,

due to habitat loss or other causes.

The Indianapolis Zoo supports

scientists at IUPU-Columbus to study

these mayflies and their habitats. More

data are needed to help update the

conservation status of mayfly species.

Macaw Recovery Network

GREAT GREEN & SCARLET MACAWS

The pet trade, hunting and habitat

loss threaten many macaw species in

Central and South America. The great

green macaw is critically endangered.

There may be only 1,000 birds left in

the wild. Since 2015, the Indianapolis

Zoo has funded research and

conservation projects of the Macaw

Recovery Network. Conservationists

plan to release more rare great green

macaws back into the wild.

National Tropical

Botanical Garden

âALULA

The âalula is a plant native to Kauaâi,

Hawaiâi. It resembles a cabbage on a

succulent stalk and is extinct in the

wild. The âalula holds a mystery.

Scientists donât know what kinds of

pollinators have helped it reproduce.

The Indianapolis Zoo supports the

National Tropical Botanical Gardenâs

efforts to identify a pollinator for the

rare âalula plant. Scientists will use

genetic techniques on museum

collections of a possibly extinct moth

species from Kauaiâi. The moths in

museums may carry pollen on their

bodies that could be matched to the âa

lula flowers. Scientists will also

observe the flowers of living âalula

plants to see what current pollinators

visit them.

2023 Annual Report 18

P:24

continued from previous page

Nigerian

Conservation Foundation

HOODED VULTURE

Vultures are valuable members of

ecosystems, scavenging food from dead

animals. Africa is home to many vulture

species, several of which are native to

Nigeria. Most are critically endangered

because of illegal trade and habitat loss.

The Indianapolis Zoo supports the

Nigerian Conservation Foundationâs

efforts to create habitat preserves for the

hooded vulture and other species. The

organization engages local youth to help

monitor and protect vultures. Scientists

are also learning more about what

vultures need to thrive.

North American Sturgeon and

Paddlefish Society

STURGEONS

Sturgeons are freshwater fish. Some species

live in Indiana, including in the White River.

Globally, all species of sturgeon, and their

relatives the paddlefish, are threatened

with extinction. Wildlife biologists have

monitored sturgeons for decades as part of

conservation programs. The Indianapolis

Zoo supports the North American Sturgeon

and Paddlefish Society in standardizing

ways for people to handle sturgeons. Their

work will ensure these rare fish are cared for

in the best way possible.

Oklahoma

Zoological Society

GUATEMALAN BEADED LIZARDS

The Guatemalan beaded lizard is native

to the dry forests of Guatemala. It

lives in ground burrows made by other

animals, as well as in tree and cliff

holes. This lizard was once widespread

in dry tropical forests, but its

populations are shrinking. It is now an

endangered species because of

deforestation and the climate crisis.

The Indianapolis Zoo supports the

Oklahoma Zoological Society as it

educates communities about the value

of these lizards. Their campaign

empowers local residents to act as

âGuardians of the Forestâ to protect

dry forests and the beaded lizard.

South African National

Biodiversity Institute

MEDICINAL PLANTS

Many plants contain chemicals that

can act as medicines. Traditional

cultures and modern medicine both

rely on plants for current and new

therapies. Some plants with known

medicinal properties are threatened

with extinction in the wild. The

Indianapolis Zoo supports the South

African National Biodiversity

Instituteâs work to conserve

threatened medicinal plant species.

Working with people across southern

Africa, the organization is creating a

regional conservation plan. This

project will help people grow more

plants and manage their resources

sustainably for the future.

19 IndianapolisZoo.com

P:25

Tanzania Conservation

and Research Program

AFRICAN ELEPHANTS

The Tarangire ecosystem in Tanzania is

home to many kinds of migrating large

mammals, such as elephants, lions,

giraffes and wildebeest. Since 2007,

the Indianapolis Zoo has supported

the Tanzania Conservation and

Research Program to protect large

African mammals. Wildlife corridors

help create spaces for wildlife,

livestock and people to live together.

World Parrot Trust

BLUE-THROATED MACAWS

The World Parrot Trust has worked to

protect the blue-throated macaw by

studying their ecology, protecting wild

nests, conducting habitat studies,

monitoring breeding pairs and installing

artificial nest boxes. While building a

captive breeding program based in

Bolivia, the project is also dedicated to

providing community education

opportunities. The Indianapolis Zooâs

support will assist with the

establishment of a blue-throated

macaw field station within the newly

designated Gran Mojos Reserve.

Great green macaw

Ara ambiguus

at the Zoo

The Indianapolis Zoo is home to more than 1,550 animals, representing hundreds of

species. Many of these species are classified as endangered or threatened in the

wild. By staying committed to our mission of protecting nature and inspiring people

to care for our world, we aim to make a difference for species around the globe.

botanical garden. Our talented horticulture team

maintains a beautiful entry experience through

matching each biome.

2023 Annual Report 26

P:32

VETERINARY TEAMâS

Record Year

The Indianapolis Zoo veterinary team had a record-breaking year for research,

including five published studies on care provided to orangutans, smooth dogfish,

painted turtles and African elephants. The research and expertise from our Zooâs

vet team is making a difference in the care of animals around the world.

Hoffmanâs two-toed sloth

Choloepus hoffmani

Elephant Calfâs

Birth Makes History

Labor Day weekend was history-making for the Indianapolis Zoo

with first-time elephant mother Zahara giving birth to male calf

Jabari. The birth made history as the first elephant in the

world (African or Asian) to be born through artificial

insemination to a mother who was also born through the

same procedure. Jabariâs grandmother, Ivory, is also part

of the Zooâs herd.

Jabari was the seventh calf to be born at the Indianapolis

Zoo. Our Zoo is recognized as a leader in African

elephant reproduction. The first and second African

elephants in the world to be conceived and successfully

born through artificial insemination were at the Indianapolis

Zoo in 2000. Multi-generational herds are the most natural and

healthy social setting for elephants and are essential to educate Zoo

visitors and foster a conservation mindset.

African elephant

Loxodonta africana

P:33

Intern Spotlight:

Dr. Samantha Bradley

Dr. Samantha Bradley is the Indianapolis Zooâs

newest Harlan Family Veterinary Intern. After

completing veterinary school, Dr. Bradley

specifically sought out the Indianapolis Zooâs

internship program, thanks to hearing high praise

from a fellow student.

Since the start of her internship, Dr. Bradley has

been a part of several day-to-day procedures.

From physical exams of lizards and kangaroos to

ultrasounds of elephants and giraffes, she has

done it all. While working with animals does

sound fun, veterinary medicine is not an easy

career to pursue. This program is a constant

reminder of how zoo vets play a vital role in

preserving animal health and well-being. The

Zooâs Harlan Family Veterinary Internship

position is made possible by a generous gift from

the Harlan Family.

Aardvark

Orycteropus afer

Meerkat

VOLUNTEER

Impact

Indianapolis Zoo volunteers are a critical part of our team. We rely on our dedicated

volunteers who make the experience of visiting the Zoo special. Our volunteers work

in many areas, including guest experiences, education, animal care, horticulture,

research and Zoo events. In 2023, our volunteers created more than 1,900 animal

enrichment items.

COMMUNITY

Partnership

The Zoo makes it a priority to engage local youth and provide meaningful

professional development opportunities. In 2016, the Zoo launched a partnership

with Providence Cristo Rey High School, a Catholic college and career preparatory

high school in Indianapolis, bringing students to the Zoo for a year-long internship.

Student interns are introduced to career opportunities and spend time working in

various departments, including animal care, education and human resources. One

student, Kohlvin (pictured below), made time to care for the chickens during the

xZooberance spring festival.

The Zooâs partnership with Technology Recyclers provided a convenient way for our community to

keep electronic waste out of landfills. In total, our guests donated nearly 42,000 pounds of waste,

including televisions, computers, phones and appliances.

The Zoo offers unique programs

EVENT-FUL FUN

at the Zoo

The xZOOberance Spring Festival,

ZooBoo presented by Central Indiana

Honda Dealers, and Christmas at the

Zoo presented by CareSource drew in

record crowds in 2023. Visitors from

Central Indiana and beyond have

made a visit to the Zoo one of their

holiday traditions.

This yearâs ZooBoo recorded the

highest attendance in the history of

the event. The Zoo also won two

Emmy awards for the creative and

spooky ZooBoo commercial.

Now in its 57th year, Christmas at the

Zoo is Indianapolisâ longest-running

holiday light event. This yearâs event

featured more than 750,000

twinkling lights.

For more than two decades, the

Elegant Vintages International

Wine Auction, presented by Busey

Bank, has served wine enthusiastsâ

wildest dreams while contributing to

the Zooâs conservation mission. The

2023 Wine Auction raised $433,000

to support the care and feeding of

the Zooâs animals and plants.

Zoobilation, presented by AES Indiana,

is Indyâs most-anticipated event of the

year and the Midwestâs largest black-tie

fundraising event. In 2023, this party

with a purpose raised more than $2.6

million for the Zooâs animal care and

conservation goals.

Brewfari, presented by Scarlet Lane

Diversity,Equity and Inclusion

Indianapolis Zoo Diversity Statement:

The Indianapolis Zoo is committed to creating and maintaining a diverse and

inclusive culture where everyone feels welcome and respected. We are committed

to maintaining an environment of inclusion and understanding that does not

tolerate hate or racism in any form.

The Indianapolis Zoo established clear goals to track progress. A workplace

comprised of individuals from diverse backgrounds fosters innovation, inclusion

and excellence.

1 Attract, recruit and retain a qualified, committed, and diverse staff, board and

volunteer corps where everyone feels empowered and respected.

accessible and promote a sense of welcoming and belonging.

consistent with the Zooâs nine-county core market demographics.
